title: Introduction to Variables
description: Understanding that a letter (like a, x, or y) can represent an unknown number or quantity. This is the foundation of algebraic thinking.
learning_objectives: Understand that a letter can represent an unknown number
Relate variables to boxes or blanks in equations

visual_elements.description: Box diagrams showing □ + 4 = 10 converting to x + 4 = 10

real_world_examples: Using boxes to represent unknown quantities: □ + 4 = 10
Age problems: 'Let my age be represented by the letter a'

interactive_activities.title: Box to Variable Converter
interactive_activities.description: Convert box equations to variable equations

common_misconceptions: Thinking that different letters represent different unknown quantities
Not understanding that the same letter always represents the same value

title: Simple Algebraic Expressions
description: Learning to write and interpret simple algebraic expressions like 3a, a + 5, 2x - 3, and understanding their meaning.

visual_elements.description: Visual representation of expressions using blocks and symbols

real_world_examples: Cost calculation: If one pen costs $3, then 'a' pens cost $3a
Savings: If I save $5 every week, after 'w' weeks I have $5w
Temperature: If today is 3°C warmer than yesterday (y°C), today is (y + 3)°C

interactive_activities.title: Build the Expression
interactive_activities.description: Create algebraic expressions from word descriptions

common_misconceptions: Writing 'a3' instead of '3a' for 'three times a'

title: Substitution and Evaluation
description: Learning to substitute values for variables and evaluate algebraic expressions, like finding the value of 3p + 7 when p = 4.
real_world_examples: Temperature conversion: If C = 25, find F = 1.8C + 32
Taxi fare: If distance is 5km, find cost = 3d + 5
Recipe scaling: If recipe serves 4, ingredients for 6 people
common_misconceptions: Forgetting to multiply the coefficient by the variable value
Not using parentheses when substituting negative values

title: Simple Linear Equations
description: Learning to solve simple linear equations involving one variable, like x + 5 = 12 or 3y = 21, using inverse operations.
learning_objectives: Solve simple linear equations with one variable
Use inverse operations to isolate variables

visual_elements.description: Balance scale showing equation solving process

real_world_examples: Shopping: If you buy x items at $5 each and spend $25, how many items? 5x = 25
Age problems: If I'm 3 years older than my sister and I'm 15, how old is she? s + 3 = 15
Savings: If I save $10 weekly and have $80, how many weeks? 10w = 80

interactive_activities.title: Balance the Scale
interactive_activities.description: Use balance scales to understand equation solving

common_misconceptions: Doing the same operation to both sides instead of inverse operations
Not performing operations on both sides of the equation
Getting confused about which operation to do first

title: Word Problems and Applications
description: Translating word problems into algebraic equations and solving them. This includes problems about age, money, geometry, and other real-world contexts.
learning_objectives: Translate word problems into algebraic equations
Identify the unknown quantity and define variables

visual_elements.description: Visual guide for converting words to equations

real_world_examples: Age problems: 'Ben is 3 years older than Alice. Together they are 25 years old.'
Money problems: 'Sarah has $12 more than Tom. Together they have $48.'
Geometry: 'A rectangle's length is 5cm more than its width. The area is 84 cm².'
Consecutive numbers: 'Find three consecutive numbers that sum to 96.'

interactive_activities.title: Words to Equations
interactive_activities.description: Practice translating word problems to algebraic equations

interactive_activities.title: Does the Answer Make Sense?
interactive_activities.description: Check if algebraic solutions make sense in real-world context

common_misconceptions: Not defining what the variable represents clearly
Setting up equations incorrectly from word problems
Not checking if the solution makes sense in context
Confusing 'more than' and 'times' in word problems
